headline: Grass may look greener on the other side
pros: Opportunities for growth, Friendly, Flexible, Multicultural, get to learn.
cons:
This is based on my personal experience and after my discussions with 5 other people from the company.

1. Read the job description 10 times because what you read and expect is not what you will get to do.
2. HR is pretty much useless.
3. You will be negotiating salary with your senior and not the HR, which means there's very low chances of you getting paid based on your experience but instead you'll be relying your senior.
4. You'll be paying for everything including visa fee, tickets, hotel etc.
5. HR will promise you many about how they will be supporting you and all but when the time comes, there will be no one to help you, you will be on your own. 
6. No one will help you find a flat, and the German language is not going to help.
7.HR will be putting a lot of pressure on you to get you all the required documents like KVR registration, police certificate, bank account etc but no help from them to sort these out.
8. There are a thousand teams that you will have to figure out on your own and not even one person would want to answer your questions with authority and responsibility.  They will tell you something and then ask you to confirm with 10 other teams....it's like corona virus...the questions keep travelling.
9. Lack of time management.  People tend to have 10 meetings just for a very small, not so important thing...something that can be answered by a responsible team or person (if that existed). Read #8
10. If you like to take responsibility and manage something personally, this is not the place. Read 8 and 9 + hierarchy.

headline: Exciting company, that allows a lot of space for self-fulfillment
pros:
Wirecard is a young and dynamic company that has been growing quickly in the past years. What I really enjoy about my work here is that you don't have the feeling to be a small wheel in the big machinery. Instead, you can really see the outcome of your work - you can make a difference. 
You have to be a person who is willing to pave and go his/ her own way, and you should bring some serenity if things don't work out right away. But then this is an incredibly exciting place to work, as your self-efficacy is so high and there's always a chance to get involved in cool new projects.
cons: Since processes didn't grow as fast as the number of employees, it can be challenging for people who have a strong need for structures. But it's always about what you make out of it ;)

headline: If everything would look as positive as the stock's value does
pros:
- depending on the manager and team, it can be a great experience
- if your manager wants to invest in you, the manager will do it (and I'm lucky to have such a manager)
- the bonus is quite good (also depending on the manager)
- you might meet some really great people in the company to hang out with and work together on solving problems or making things better in your area
cons:
- no real investment in the infrastructure and the people providing the 24/7 operations, the salary is sub-par for a DAX company with overflowing earnings
- ongoing mismanagement by not clearly having a focus since growth is the only goal while quality and efficiency doesn't seem to matter
- feedback is welcome, everybody listens, but nobody acts on it properly or provides valuable actionable feedback to the employee
- lots of pressure to meet very tight dead lines, which are very often missed due to the lacking investment of the past years
- too high expectations on the capabilities of the teams, which are sometimes too small to actually provide good quality
- at times it can be very chaotic when it comes to defining priorities for tasks / projects

headline: Looks good on the surface...
pros: Gym, international working environment, german classes, nice little coffeeshop/bistro inhouse. Flexible working hours, as most Munich based companies you also get to go to the Oktoberfest.
cons:
Where do I start? 

There are little to no chance of improving yourself in the technical side of things, also a very big struggle to get promoted, big promises with no execution or constant "change of priorities" hamper any progress. There is little room for R&D with new technologies: Docker, forget about it. Personal VMs: forget about it.  
Also no transparency with regards to the structure and for planning your career here.
A very cliquey culture centred around partying and being one of the "boys", disregard this and you can forget any advancement.

Home office is not an option, however if you know the right people it seems that it is possible, even on a weekly basis, got love the favouritism at play here.

My biggest gripe  is the complete lack of competent management on some levels. They would rather employ more low paid employees than to improve their existing ones, the same employees who then take double the time to be on-boarded and also lack some basic IT skills and no independent thought and action. 
Management also means earning the respect of your team, to lead them. Not let them fend for themselves but then play important when projects are running late. Constantly having to escalate basic level tickets, having to explain to other employees how to do their job is not my job nor is it making it an enjoyable working atmosphere.
